1.1: Love righteousness, all you who are judges of the earth.
1.2: because he is found by those who don’t put him to the test,
1.3: for crooked thoughts separate from God.
1.4: because wisdom will not enter into a soul that devises evil,
1.5: For a holy spirit of discipline will flee deceit,
1.6: For wisdom is a spirit who loves man,
1.7: Because the spirit of the Lord has filled the world,
1.8: Therefore no one who utters unrighteous things will be unseen;
1.9: For in his counsels the ungodly will be searched out,
1.10: because a jealous ear listens to all things,
1.12: Don’t court death in the error of your life.
1.14: For he created all things that they might have being.
1.16: but ungodly men by their hands and their words summon death;

2.1: For they said within themselves, with unsound reasoning,
2.2: Because we were born by mere chance,
2.3: which being extinguished, the body will be turned into ashes,
2.4: Our name will be forgotten in time.
2.5: For our allotted time is the passing of a shadow,
2.6: “Come therefore and let’s enjoy the good things that exist.
2.7: Let’s fill ourselves with costly wine and perfumes,
2.8: Let’s crown ourselves with rosebuds before they wither.
2.9: Let none of us go without his share in our proud revelry.
2.11: But let our strength be a law of righteousness;
2.12: But let’s lie in wait for the righteous man,
2.13: He professes to have knowledge of God,
2.14: He became to us a reproof of our thoughts.
2.15: He is grievous to us even to look at,
2.16: We were regarded by him as something worthless,
2.17: Let’s see if his words are true.
2.18: For if the righteous man is God’s son, he will uphold him,
2.19: Let’s test him with insult and torture,
2.20: Let’s condemn him to a shameful death,
2.21: Thus they reasoned, and they were led astray;
2.22: and they didn’t know the mysteries of God,
2.23: Because God created man for incorruption,
2.24: but death entered into the world by the envy of the devil,

3.1: But the souls of the righteous are in the hand of God,
3.2: In the eyes of the foolish they seemed to have died.
3.3: and their travel away from us ruin,
3.4: For even if in the sight of men they are punished,
3.5: Having borne a little chastening, they will receive great good;
3.6: He tested them like gold in the furnace,
3.7: In the time of their visitation they will shine.
3.8: They will judge nations and have dominion over peoples.
3.9: Those who trust him will understand truth.
3.10: But the ungodly will be punished even as their reasoning deserves,
3.11: for he who despises wisdom and discipline is miserable.
3.12: Their wives are foolish and their children are wicked.
3.14: So is the eunuch which has done no lawless deed with his hands,
3.15: For good labors have fruit of great renown.
3.16: But children of adulterers will not come to maturity.
3.17: For if they live long, they will not be esteemed,
3.18: If they die young, they will have no hope,
3.19: For the end of an unrighteous generation is always grievous.

4.1: It is better to be childless with virtue,
4.2: When it is present, people imitate it.
4.3: But the multiplying brood of the ungodly will be of no profit,
4.4: For even if they grow branches and flourish for a season,
4.5: Their branches will be broken off before they come to maturity.
4.6: For unlawfully conceived children are witnesses of wickedness
4.7: But a righteous man, even if he dies before his time, will be at rest.
4.8: For honorable old age is not that which stands in length of time,
4.9: but understanding is gray hair to men,
4.10: Being found well-pleasing to God, someone was loved.
4.11: He was caught away, lest evil should change his understanding,
4.12: For the fascination of wickedness obscures the things which are good,
4.14: for his soul was pleasing to the Lord.
4.15: But the peoples saw and didn’t understand,
4.16: but a righteous man who is dead will condemn the ungodly who are living,
4.17: For the ungodly will see a wise man’s end,
4.18: They will see, and they will despise;
4.19: because he will dash them speechless to the ground,
4.20: They will come with coward fear when their sins are counted.

5.1: Then the righteous man will stand in great boldness
5.2: When they see him, they will be troubled with terrible fear,
5.3: They will speak among themselves repenting,
5.4: We fools considered his life madness,
5.5: How was he counted among sons of God?
5.6: Truly we went astray from the way of truth.
5.7: We took our fill of the paths of lawlessness and destruction.
5.8: What did our arrogance profit us?
5.9: Those things all passed away as a shadow,
5.10: like a ship passing through the billowy water,
5.11: Or it is like when a bird flies through the air,
5.12: Or it is like when an arrow is shot at a mark,
5.13: So we also, as soon as we were born, ceased to be;
5.14: Because the hope of the ungodly man is like chaff carried by the wind,
5.16: Therefore they will receive the crown of royal dignity
5.17: He will take his zeal as complete armor,
5.18: He will put on righteousness as a breastplate,
5.19: He will take holiness as an invincible shield.
5.20: He will sharpen stern wrath for a sword.
5.21: Shafts of lightning will fly with true aim.
5.22: Hailstones full of wrath will be hurled as from a catapult.
5.23: A mighty wind will encounter them.

6.1: Hear therefore, you kings, and understand.
6.2: Give ear, you rulers who have dominion over many people,
6.3: because your dominion was given to you from the Lord,
6.4: because being officers of his kingdom, you didn’t judge rightly,
6.5: He will come upon you awfully and swiftly,
6.6: For the man of low estate may be pardoned in mercy,
6.7: For the Sovereign Lord of all will not be impressed with anyone,
6.8: but the scrutiny that comes upon the powerful is strict.
6.9: Therefore, my words are to you, O princes,
6.10: For those who have kept the things that are holy in holiness will be made holy.
6.11: Therefore set your desire on my words.
6.12: Wisdom is radiant and doesn’t fade away;
6.13: She anticipates those who desire her, making herself known.
6.14: He who rises up early to seek her won’t have difficulty,
6.15: For to think upon her is perfection of understanding,
6.16: because she herself goes around, seeking those who are worthy of her,
6.17: For her true beginning is desire for instruction;
6.18: And love is observance of her laws.
6.20: So then desire for wisdom promotes to a kingdom.
6.21: If therefore you delight in thrones and sceptres, you princes of peoples,
6.22: But what wisdom is, and how she came into being, I will declare.
6.23: Indeed, I won’t travel with consuming envy,
6.24: But a multitude of wise men is salvation to the world,
6.25: Therefore be instructed by my words, and you will profit.

7.1: I myself am also mortal, like everyone else,
7.2: I molded into flesh in the time of ten months in my mother’s womb,
7.3: I also, when I was born, drew in the common air,
7.4: I was nursed with care in swaddling clothes.
7.5: For no king had a different beginning,
7.6: but all men have one entrance into life, and a common departure.
7.7: For this cause I prayed, and understanding was given to me.
7.8: I preferred her before sceptres and thrones.
7.9: Neither did I liken to her any priceless gem,
7.10: I loved her more than health and beauty,
7.11: All good things came to me with her,
7.12: And I rejoiced over them all because wisdom leads them;
7.13: As I learned without guile, I impart without grudging.
7.14: For she is a treasure for men that doesn’t fail,
7.15: But may God grant that I may speak his judgment,
7.16: For both we and our words are in his hand,
7.17: For he himself gave me an unerring knowledge of the things that are,
7.18: the beginning, end, and middle of times;
7.19: the circuits of years and the positions of stars;
7.20: the natures of living creatures and the raging of wild beasts;
7.21: All things that are either secret or manifest I learned,
7.22: for wisdom, that is the architect of all things, taught me.
7.23: beneficent, loving toward man, steadfast, sure, free from care, all-powerful, all-surveying,
7.24: For wisdom is more mobile than any motion.
7.25: For she is a breath of the power of God,
7.26: For she is a reflection of everlasting light,
7.27: Although she is one, she has power to do all things.
7.28: For God loves nothing as much as one who dwells with wisdom.
7.29: For she is fairer than the sun,

8.1: But she reaches from one end to the other with full strength,
8.2: I loved her and sought her from my youth.
8.3: She glorifies her noble birth by living with God.
8.4: For she is initiated into the knowledge of God,
8.5: But if riches are a desired possession in life,
8.8: And if anyone longs for wide experience,
8.9: Therefore I determined to take her to live with me,
8.10: Because of her, I will have glory among multitudes,
8.11: I will be found keen when I give judgment.
8.12: When I am silent, they will wait for me.
8.13: Because of her, I will have immortality,
8.15: Dreaded monarchs will fear me when they hear of me.
8.16: When I come into my house, I will find rest with her.
8.17: When I considered these things in myself,
8.18: and in her friendship is good delight,
8.19: Now I was a clever child, and received a good soul.
8.20: Or rather, being good, I came into an undefiled body.
8.21: But perceiving that I could not otherwise possess wisdom unless God gave her to me—

9.1: “O God of my ancestors and Lord of mercy,
9.2: and by your wisdom you formed man,
9.3: and rule the world in holiness and righteousness,
9.4: give me wisdom, her who sits by you on your thrones.
9.5: because I am your servant and the son of your handmaid,
9.6: For even if a man is perfect among the sons of men,
9.7: You chose me to be king of your people,
9.8: You gave a command to build a sanctuary on your holy mountain,
9.9: Wisdom is with you and knows your works,
9.10: Send her from the holy heavens,
9.11: For she knows all things and understands,
9.12: So my works will be acceptible.
9.13: For what man will know the counsel of God?
9.14: For the thoughts of mortals are unstable,
9.15: For a corruptible body weighs down the soul.
9.16: We can hardly guess the things that are on earth,
9.17: Who gained knowledge of your counsel, unless you gave wisdom,
9.18: It was thus that the ways of those who are on earth were corrected,

10.1: Wisdom guarded to the end the first formed father of the world, who was created alone,
10.2: and gave him strength to rule over all things.
10.3: But when an unrighteous man fell away from her in his anger,
10.4: When for his cause the earth was drowning with a flood,
10.5: Moreover, when nations consenting together in wickedness had been confounded,
10.6: While the ungodly were perishing, wisdom delivered a righteous man,
10.7: To whose wickedness a smoking waste still witnesses,
10.9: but wisdom delivered those who waited on her out of troubles.
10.10: When a righteous man was a fugitive from a brother’s wrath, wisdom guided him in straight paths.
10.11: When in their covetousness men dealt harshly with him,
10.13: When a righteous man was sold, wisdom didn’t forsake him,
10.14: and in bonds she didn’t depart from him,
10.15: Wisdom delivered a holy people and a blameless seed from a nation of oppressors.
10.16: She entered into the soul of a servant of the Lord,
10.17: She rendered to holy men a reward of their toils.
10.18: She brought them over the Red sea,
10.20: Therefore the righteous plundered the ungodly,
10.21: because wisdom opened the mouth of the mute,

11.1: Wisdom prospered their works in the hand of a holy prophet.
11.2: They traveled through a desert without inhabitant,
11.3: They withstood enemies and repelled foes.
11.4: They thirsted, and they called upon you,
11.5: For by what things their foes were punished,
11.6: When enemies were troubled with clotted blood
11.7: to rebuke the decree for the slaying of babies,
11.8: having shown by the thirst which they had suffered
11.9: For when they were tried, although chastened in mercy,
11.10: For you tested these as a father admonishing them;
11.11: Yes and whether they were far off or near,
11.12: for a double grief seized them,
11.13: For when they heard that through their own punishments the others benefited,
11.14: For him who long before was thrown out and exposed they stopped mocking.
11.15: But in return for the senseless imaginings of their unrighteousness,
11.16: that they might learn that by what things a man sins, by these he is punished.
11.18: or newly-created and unknown wild beasts, full of rage,
11.19: which had power not only to consume them by their violence,
11.20: Yes and without these they might have fallen by a single breath,
11.21: For to be greatly strong is yours at all times.
11.22: Because the whole world before you is as a grain in a balance,
11.23: But you have mercy on all men, because you have power to do all things,
11.24: For you love all things that are,
11.25: How would anything have endured unless you had willed it?
11.26: But you spare all things, because they are yours,

12.1: For your incorruptible spirit is in all things.
12.2: Therefore you convict little by little those who fall from the right way,
12.3: For truly the old inhabitants of your holy land,
12.4: hating them because they practiced detestable works of enchantments and unholy rites—
12.7: that the land which in your sight is most precious of all
12.8: Nevertheless you even spared these as men,
12.9: Not that you were unable to subdue the ungodly under the hand of the righteous in battle,
12.10: but judging them little by little you gave them a chance to repent,
12.11: For they were a cursed seed from the beginning.
12.12: For who will say, “What have you done?”
12.13: For there isn’t any God beside you that cares for all,
12.14: No king or prince will be able to confront you
12.15: But being righteous, you rule all things righteously,
12.16: For your strength is the source of righteousness,
12.17: For when men don’t believe that you are perfect in power, you show your strength,
12.18: But you, being sovereign in strength, judge in gentleness,
12.19: But you taught your people by such works as these,
12.20: For if on those who were enemies of your servants and deserving of death,
12.21: with how great care you judged your sons,
12.22: Therefore while you chasten us, you scourge our enemies ten thousand times more,
12.23: Therefore also the unrighteous that lived in a life of folly,
12.24: For truly they went astray very far in the ways of error,
12.25: Therefore, as to unreasoning children, you sent your judgment to mock them.
12.26: But those who would not be admonished by mild correction
12.27: For through the sufferings they were indignant of,

13.1: For truly all men who had no perception of God were foolish by nature,
13.2: But they thought that either fire, or wind, or swift air,
13.3: If it was through delight in their beauty that they took them to be gods,
13.4: But if it was through astonishment at their power and influence,
13.5: For from the greatness of the beauty of created things,
13.6: But yet for these men there is but small blame,
13.7: For they diligently search while living among his works,
13.8: But again even they are not to be excused.
13.9: For if they had power to know so much,
13.10: But they were miserable, and their hopes were in dead things,
13.11: Yes and some woodcutter might saw down a tree that is easily moved,
13.12: Burning the scraps from his handiwork to cook his food,
13.13: Taking a discarded scrap which served no purpose,
13.14: or makes it like some worthless animal,
13.15: Having made a worthy chamber for it,
13.16: He plans for it that it may not fall down,
13.17: When he makes his prayer concerning goods and his marriage and children,
13.18: Yes, for health, he calls upon that which is weak.
13.19: And for profit in business and good success of his hands,

14.1: Again, one preparing to sail, and about to journey over raging waves,
14.2: For the hunger for profit planned it,
14.3: Your providence, O Father, guides it along,
14.4: showing that you can save out of every danger,
14.5: It is your will that the works of your wisdom should not be ineffective.
14.6: For in the old time also, when proud giants were perishing,
14.7: For blessed is wood through which comes righteousness;
14.8: but the idol made with hands is accursed, itself and he that made it;
14.9: For both the ungodly and his ungodliness are alike hateful to God;
14.10: for truly the deed will be punished together with him who committed it.
14.11: Therefore also there will be a visitation among the idols of the nation,
14.12: For the devising of idols was the beginning of fornication,
14.13: For they didn’t exist from the beginning, and they won’t exist forever.
14.14: For by the boastfulness of men they entered into the world,
14.15: For a father worn with untimely grief,
14.16: Afterward the ungodly custom, in process of time grown strong, was kept as a law,
14.17: And when men could not honor them in presence because they lived far off,
14.18: But worship was raised to a yet higher pitch, even by those who didn’t know him,
14.19: for he, wishing perhaps to please his ruler,
14.20: So the multitude, allured by reason of the grace of his handiwork,
14.22: Afterward it was not enough for them to go astray concerning the knowledge of God,
14.23: For either slaughtering children in solemn rites, or celebrating secret mysteries,
14.24: no longer do they guard either life or purity of marriage,
14.25: And all things confusedly are filled with blood and murder, theft and deceit,
14.26: confusion about what is good, forgetfulness of favors,
14.27: For the worship of idols that may not be named
14.28: For their worshipers either make merry to madness, or prophesy lies,
14.29: For putting their trust in lifeless idols,
14.30: But on both counts, the just doom will pursue them,
14.31: For it is not the power of things by which men swear,

15.1: But you, our God, are gracious and true,
15.2: For even if we sin, we are yours, knowing your dominion;
15.3: For to be acquainted with you is perfect righteousness,
15.4: For we weren’t led astray by any evil plan of men’s,
15.5: the sight of which leads fools into lust.
15.6: Lovers of evil things, and worthy of such hopes,
15.7: For a potter, kneading soft earth,
15.8: Also, laboring to an evil end, he molds a vain god out of the same clay,
15.11: because he was ignorant of him who molded him,
15.12: But he accounted our life to be a game,
15.13: For this man, beyond all others, knows that he sins,
15.14: But most foolish and more miserable than a baby,
15.15: because they even considered all the idols of the nations to be gods,
15.17: But, being mortal, he makes a dead thing by the work of lawless hands;
15.18: Yes, and they worship the creatures that are most hateful,
15.19: Neither, as seen beside other creatures, are they beautiful, so that one should desire them,

16.1: For this cause, they were deservedly punished through creatures like those which they worship,
16.2: Instead of this punishment, you, giving benefits to your people,
16.3: to the end that your enemies, desiring food,
16.4: For it was necessary that inescapable lack should come upon those oppressors,
16.5: For even when terrible raging of wild beasts came upon your people,
16.6: but for admonition were they troubled for a short time,
16.7: for he who turned toward it was not saved because of that which was seen,
16.8: Yes, and in this you persuaded our enemies
16.9: For the bites of locusts and flies truly killed them.
16.10: But your children weren’t overcome by the very fangs of venomous dragons,
16.11: For they were bitten to put them in remembrance of your oracles,
16.12: For truly it was neither herb nor poultice that cured them,
16.13: For you have authority over life and death,
16.14: But though a man kills by his wickedness,
16.15: But it is not possible to escape your hand;
16.16: for ungodly men, refusing to know you, were scourged in the strength of your arm,
16.18: For at one time the flame was restrained,
16.19: At another time even in the midst of water it burns more intensely than fire,
16.20: Instead of these things, you gave your people angels’ food to eat,
16.21: For your nature showed your sweetness toward your children,
16.22: But snow and ice endured fire, and didn’t melt,
16.23: and that this fire, again, in order that righteous people may be nourished,
16.24: For the creation, ministering to you, its maker,
16.25: Therefore at that time also, converting itself into all forms,
16.26: that your children, whom you loved, O Lord, might learn
16.27: For that which was not destroyed by fire,
16.28: that it might be known that we must rise before the sun to give you thanks,
16.29: for the hope of the unthankful will melt as the winter’s hoar frost,

17.1: For your judgments are great, and hard to interpret;
17.2: For when lawless men had supposed that they held a holy nation in their power,
17.3: For while they thought that they were unseen in their secret sins,
17.4: For neither did the dark recesses that held them guard them from fears,
17.5: And no power of fire prevailed to give light,
17.6: but only the glimmering of a self-kindled fire appeared to them, full of fear.
17.7: The mockeries of their magic arts were powerless, now,
17.8: For those who promised to drive away terrors and disorders from a sick soul,
17.9: For even if no troubling thing frighted them,
17.11: For wickedness, condemned by a witness within, is a coward thing,
17.12: For fear is nothing else but a surrender of the help which reason offers;
17.13: and from within, the expectation of being less
17.14: But they, all through the night which was powerless indeed,
17.15: now were haunted by monstrous apparitions,
17.16: So then whoever it might be, sinking down in his place,
17.17: for whether he was a farmer, or a shepherd,
17.18: Whether there was a whistling wind,
17.19: or a harsh crashing of rocks hurled down,
17.20: For the whole world was illuminated with clear light,
17.21: while over them alone was spread a heavy night,

18.1: But for your holy ones there was great light.
18.2: yet for that they do not hurt them, though wronged by them before, they are thankful;
18.3: Therefore you provided a burning pillar of fire,
18.4: For the Egyptians well deserved to be deprived of light and imprisoned by darkness,
18.5: After they had taken counsel to kill the babes of the holy ones,
18.6: Our fathers were made aware of that night beforehand,
18.7: Salvation of the righteous and destruction of the enemies was expected by your people.
18.8: For as you took vengeance on the adversaries,
18.9: For holy children of good men offered sacrifice in secret,
18.10: But the discordant cry of the enemies echoed back,
18.11: Both servant and master were punished with the same just doom,
18.12: Yes, they all together, under one form of death,
18.13: For while they were disbelieving all things by reason of the enchantments,
18.14: For while peaceful silence wrapped all things,
18.15: your all-powerful word leaped from heaven, from the royal throne,
18.16: bearing as a sharp sword your authentic commandment,
18.17: Then immediately apparitions in dreams terribly troubled them,
18.18: And each, one thrown here half dead, another there,
18.19: for the dreams, disturbing them, forewarned them of this,
18.20: The experience of death also touched the righteous,
18.21: For a blameless man hurried to be their champion,
18.23: For when the dead had already fallen in heaps one upon another,
18.24: For the whole world was pictured on his long robe,
18.25: The destroyer yielded to these, and they feared;

19.1: But indignation without mercy came upon the ungodly to the end;
19.2: how, having changed their minds to let your people go,
19.3: For while they were yet in the midst of their mourning,
19.4: For the doom which they deserved was drawing them to this end,
19.5: and that your people might journey on by a marvelous road,
19.6: For the whole creation, each part in its diverse kind, was made new again,
19.7: Then the cloud that overshadowed the camp was seen,
19.8: by which they passed over with all their army,
19.9: For like horses they roamed at large,
19.10: For they still remembered the things that happened in the time of their sojourning,
19.11: But afterwards, they also saw a new kind of birds,
19.12: for, to comfort them, quails came up for them from the sea.
19.14: For while the others didn’t receive the strangers when they came to them,
19.15: And not only so, but while punishment of some sort will come upon the former,
19.16: because these first welcomed with feastings,
19.17: And moreover they were stricken with loss of sight
19.18: For as the notes of a lute vary the character of the rhythm,
19.19: For creatures of the dry land were turned into creatures of the waters,
19.20: Fire kept the mastery of its own power in water,
19.21: On the contrary, flames didn’t consume flesh of perishable creatures that walked among them,
19.22: For in all things, O Lord, you magnified your people,
